newsitem.title: USA: Kiwi International says Aug load factor rises.
newsitem.headline: Kiwi International says Aug load factor rises.

text.p: Kiwi International Air Lines said on Monday its August load factor increased to 62 percent from 54 percent in the year ago period.
In August 1996, the company flew 11 aircraft, compared with 15 in August 1995.
The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration grounded a portion of Kiwi's fleet in late June after the agency found problems with pilot training records.

"We're pleased to see bookings bounce back after a slow June and July, which was due to the ValuJet crash and our partial grounding," president and chief executive officer Jerry Murphy said in a statement.

Murphy was referring to a crash of a Valujet Inc flight in the Florida Everglades in May, killing 110 passengers. The crash slowed passenger traffic at many low-cost carriers across the United States during the summer.

Kiwi's revenue passenger miles increased 13 percent to 121.8 million in August 1996 from 107.8 million in the year ago period. Available seat miles slipped one percent to 196.6 million in August from 198.4 million in August 1995.
Total passengers boarded increased four percent to 167,200 in August 1996 from the comparable year ago period.
